questiontext.text:
Important results in linear algebra

Consider the system of equations \(C\underline{x}=\underline{k}\). 

We are concerned with the nature of the solutions (if any) of this system. We shall see that this system only exhibits three solution types:

\(\bullet\)  The system is consistent and has a unique solution for \(\underline{x}\)

\(\bullet\)  The system is consistent and has an infinite number of solutions for \(\underline{x}\)

\(\bullet\)  The system is inconsistent and has no solution for \(\underline{x}\)

There are two basic cases to consider:

\(\det(C)\ne 0\)   or   \(\det(C)=0\)


Case 1: \(\det(C)\ne 0\)

In this case \(C^{-1}\) exists and the unique solution to \(C\underline{x}=\underline{k}\) is

\(\qquad \underline{x}=C^{-1}\underline{k}\)


Case 2: \(\det(C)=0\)

In this case \(C^{-1}\) does not exist.

  1. If \(\underline{k}\ne{\underline 0}\) the system \(C\underline{x}=\underline{k}\) either has no solutions or has an infinite number of solutions. We can use Gaussian elimination to determine which case it is. If we have no solutions then the reduced augmented matrix will have a row which is zero in all but the rightmost position; otherwise we have infinitely many solutions.
  2. If \(\underline{k}={\underline 0}\) the system \(C\underline{x}={\underline 0}\) has an infinite number of solutions.

We note that a homogeneous system

\[C\underline{x}={\underline 0}\]

has a unique solution \(\underline{x}={\underline 0}\) if \(\det(C)\ne 0\) (this is called the trivial solution) or an infinite number of solutions if \(\det(C)=0\).

Example

(Case 1) Solve the inhomogeneous system of equations

\[\left\{\begin{alignedat}{2} x_1 & {}+{} & x_2 & = 1 \\ 2x_1 & {}+{} & x_2 & = 2 \end{alignedat}\right.\]

which can be expressed as \(C\underline{x}=\underline{k}\) where

\[C=\begin{bmatrix}1&1\\ 2&1\end{bmatrix} \qquad \underline{x}=\begin{bmatrix} x_1\\ x_2\end{bmatrix} \qquad \underline{k}=\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 2\end{bmatrix}\]

Solution

Here det\((C)=-1\neq 0\).

The system of equations has the unique solution: \(\underline{x}=\left[\begin{array}{c} x_1\\ x_2\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{c} 1\\ 0 \end{array}\right] \).

Example

(Case 2.a) Examine the following inhomogeneous system for solutions

\[\left\{\begin{alignedat}{2} x_1 & {}+{} & 2x_2 & = 1 \\ 3x_1 & {}+{} & 6x_2 & = 0 \end{alignedat}\right.\]

Solution

Here \(\det(C)=\begin{vmatrix}1&2\\3&6\end{vmatrix}=0\). In this case there are no solutions.

To see this we see the first equation of the system states \(x_1+2x_2=1\) whereas the second equation (after dividing through by 3) states \(x_1+2x_2=0\), a contradiction.

Example

(Case 2.b) Solve the homogeneous system

\[\left\{\begin{alignedat}{2} x_1 & {}+{} & x_2 & = 0 \\ 2x_1 & {}+{} & 2x_2 & = 0 \end{alignedat}\right.\]

Solution

Here \(\det(C)=\begin{vmatrix}1&1\\2&2\end{vmatrix}=0\). The solutions are any pair of numbers \(\{x_1,x_2\}\) such that \(x_1=-x_2\), i.e. \(\underline{x} = \begin{bmatrix}\alpha\\-\alpha\end{bmatrix}\), where \(\alpha\) is an arbitrary element of \(\mathbb{R}\). There are an infinite number of solutions.
